data.title: From Tactical To Strategic: 2025 Japan Dividend Rebalance
data.description:
By Hyun Kang

Many investors have long viewed Japanese equities as a tactical allocation—a way to express short- or medium-term views on currencies, interest rates and valuations. Yet, currency-hedged performance from the beginning of the Abenomics era challenges that view.

In 2012, then-Prime Minister Shinzo Abe introduced Abenomics, a series of reforms aimed at stimulating economic growth through monetary easing and fiscal stimulus. Whether Abenomics was a success is still debated, but, more than a decade later, the evidence suggests one clear outcome: with a currency-hedged approach, Japan has proven to be more than a tactical trade. The WisdomTree Japan Hedged Equity Fund (DXJ) outpaced the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) since late 2012 by 37 basis points (bps) annually, while the unhedged iShares MSCI Japan ETF (EWJ) trailed SPY by almost 680 bps.

Figure 1: DXJ Performance vs. Competitors since Abenomics

Japan's stock market began to surge in early October as Sanae Takaichi, a pro-growth policy maker known for her support of expanded government spending (much like her late mentor, Shinzo Abe), assumed leadership of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party and markets priced in expectations of her becoming prime minister. The Nikkei 225 climbed to all-time highs, reflecting optimism about renewed fiscal stimulus and corporate reforms.

WisdomTree's Japan Dividend Indexes, which recently underwent their annual rebalances, offer a framework for navigating volatility as investors weigh global tensions and Japan's evolving economic outlook.

Figure 2: Nikkei 225 Index Price Levels

Tariffs have dominated recent discussions around foreign policy and trade. Japan, a major export economy, is especially exposed. A 15% tariff was established as part of a deal involving $550 billion in Japanese investments in the U.S.—lower than the 27.5% initially threatened by President Trump but significantly higher than the rate Japan enjoyed prior to his second term.

While exporters navigate tariff headwinds, a weaker yen has offered some relief, partially offsetting the pressure. Following its rally earlier this year, the current JPY/USD spot rate at the time of writing sits about 7% below its April peak.

Amid these crosscurrents, the WisdomTree Japan Hedged Equity Index—which is tilted toward dividend-paying exporters and seeks to replicate local equity returns—returned 27.94% over the one-year period ended September 30, outperforming its benchmark, the MSCI Japan index, in both Japanese yen and U.S. dollar terms. The Index is tracked by the WisdomTree Japan Hedged Equity Fund.

Figure 3: WisdomTree Japan Hedged Equity Index Total Returns

At the small-cap level, the WisdomTree Japan SmallCap Dividend Index—which provides unhedged exposure to dividend-paying small-cap Japanese equities—also outperformed its benchmark, the MSCI Japan Small Cap Index, over the same period. The Index is tracked by the WisdomTree Japan SmallCap Dividend Fund (DFJ).

Figure 4: WisdomTree Japan SmallCap Dividend Index Total Returns

Rebalance Overview

Following its rebalance, DXJ's Index slightly increased allocations to high-growth sectors like communications services, consumer discretionary, health care and information technology.

Overall, sector changes were fairly modest.

Figure 5: Sector Changes, WisdomTree Japan Hedged Equity Index

DFJ's Index increased allocations to the financials and information technology sectors while decreasing allocations to the consumer discretionary sector. Other changes were relatively muted.

Figure 6: Sector Changes, WisdomTree Japan SmallCap Dividend Index

Strengthened Fundamentals

Japan remains what our team calls the "anti-bubble," characterized by attractive valuations that are roughly 10 price-to-earnings (P/E) points below the S&P 500. Years of lower foreign fund flows have kept sentiment subdued, but Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's pro-growth agenda, centered on fiscal spending and improved shareholder distributions, could spark renewed investor interest and a potential re-rating in Japanese equities.

As a result of these rebalances, each Index saw improvements to fundamentals including dividend yield, P/E, return on assets (ROA) and return on equity (ROE).

Figure 7: Fundamentals

Figure 8: Additional Information

Important Risks Related to this Article

There are risks associated with investing, including the possible loss of principal. Foreign investing involves special risks, such as risk of loss from currency fluctuation or political or economic uncertainty.

DXJ: The Fund focuses its investments in Japan, thereby increasing the impact of events and developments in Japan that can adversely affect performance. Investments in currency involve additional special risks, such as credit risk, interest rate fluctuations and from derivative investments, which can be volatile and may be less liquid than other securities and more sensitive to the effect of varied economic conditions. As this Fund can have a high concentration in some issuers, the Fund can be adversely impacted by changes affecting those issuers. Due to the investment strategy of this Fund it may make higher capital gain distributions than other ETFs.

DFJ: Funds focusing their investments on smaller companies or certain sectors increase their vulnerability to any single economic or regulatory development. The Fund focuses its investments in Japan, thereby increasing the impact of events and developments in Japan that can adversely affect performance. This may result in greater share price volatility.

Please read the Fund’s prospectus for specific details regarding the Fund’s risk profile.

SPY: The fund is subject to risk, including possible loss of principal. The fund seeks to track the performance of the S&P 500 Index and does not attempt to outperform it. Equity securities may fluctuate in value in response to the activities of individual companies and general market and economic conditions. The fund is subject to general market risk, equity investing risk, and passive investment risk. ETFs may trade at prices above or below their net asset value (NAV) and are subject to brokerage commissions and trading costs.

Before investing, consider the fund’s investment objectives, risks, charges, and expenses. For more information, obtain a prospectus or summary prospectus at www.ssga.com or call 1-866-787-2257. Read it carefully.

EWJ: Carefully consider the Fund’s investment objectives, risk factors, and charges and expenses before investing. This and other information can be found in the Fund’s prospectus, and if available, summary prospectus, which may be obtained by calling 1-800-iShares (1-800-474-2737) or visiting iShares.com. Read the prospectus carefully before investing.

Investing involves risk, including possible loss of principal. International investing involves risks, including risks related to foreign currency, limited liquidity, less government regulation, and the possibility of substantial volatility due to adverse political, economic, or other developments. These risks are often heightened for investments in emerging or developing markets or in concentrations of single countries. Diversification may not protect against market risk or loss of principal. Shares of ETFs are bought and sold at market price (not NAV) and are not individually redeemed from the fund. Any applicable brokerage commissions will reduce returns. Past performance does not guarantee future results.

Hyun Kang, Research Analyst

Hyun Kang joined WisdomTree in July 2022 as a Research Analyst. As a part of the Index team, he assists with the creation and maintenance of the firm’s indexes and supports the group's research initiatives across various strategies. Hyun graduated from Carnegie Mellon University, with a B.S. in Business Administration and an additional major in Statistics and Machine Learning.

data.title: SmartCentres REIT: A Quality Operator With A Leveraged Growth Profile (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
Author's note: All figures in Canadian currency unless otherwise stated.

Investment Thesis

SmartCentres Real Estate Investment Trust (SRU.UN:CA) is a high-quality retail-focused REIT offering attractive monthly income. The REIT is advancing a pipeline of development and intensification projects that leverage some of SmartCentres existing urban locations. This growth strategy has contributed to revenue diversification and added residential and storage properties to the portfolio. Despite the attractive property portfolio and growth prospects, SmartCentres' debt burden may limit the REIT's capacity to advance developments.

REIT Profile

SmartCentres owns and operates a diversified and fully integrated real estate portfolio. With 197 properties and nearly $12B in assets, it is one of Canada’s largest REITs. SmartCentres is best known for its status as Walmart’s (WMT) landlord, these Walmart properties contribute nearly one quarter of revenue. 114 of the REIT's properties are Walmart-anchored centers.

SmartCentres traces its origins to the 1980s, when its founder and CEO, Mitchell Goldhar, helped bring Walmart to Canada. Goldhar entered into a joint venture with Walmart in 100 shopping centres. Mitchell Goldhar, owns a 20% equity stake in the trust, ensuring alignment between management and the value-creating interests of unit holders. Golhar continues to buy units of SmartCentres, with a notable purchase of 43,700 units in December 2024 for $1.1M. SmartCentres has a market capitalization of $4.6B and an enterprise value of $10.1B.

In 2015, SmartCentres merged with Calloway REIT, incorporating its development arm and a broader property portfolio. In the decade since that merger, SmartCentres has diversified to include residential, including condos, townhomes, apartments, and self-storage. The REIT owns 35 million square feet of income producing properties and 3,500 acres of land. SmartCentres is advancing an ambitious development pipeline of 86 million square feet of mixed-use developments. SmartCentres trades at 13.5X trailing AFFO, in line with its historical range.

Operations

As a reflection of the REIT's high-quality tenant mix, SmartCentres has a long track record of industry-leading occupancy levels. While occupancy on existing sites has been consistently strong, the REIT notes growing demand for new-build retail. For leases expiring in 2025, SmartCentres has completed extensions for 82% of upcoming maturities.

Same-property NOI growth in the second quarter of 2025 was 4.8% across the whole portfolio and 7.7% excluding anchor tenants. On the latest earnings call, the company guided towards the middle of its annualized 3-5% same-property NOI growth for the full year.

Densification Opportunity

SmartCentres' most compelling growth opportunity is through the intensification of its current retail sites. To that end, SmartCentres is advancing an ambitious pipeline of development projects, many of which are mixed-use. Often achieved as part of a joint venture, this densification process has included self-storage, condos, town homes and apartments alongside retail.

SmartCentres has zoning approval for relevant development types for over two-thirds of the 86 million square feet identified for future mixed-use development. The REIT's ability to execute its densification option will be highly correlated to its balance sheet flexibility to execute large projects. For a close look at SmartCentres densification strategy, see my previous coverage: SmartCentres REIT: Smart Value Creation Through Intensification

Distribution

SmartCentres has paid a distribution for 22 consecutive years. During this period, the REIT has reliably and consistently paid unit holders. At current unit prices, the annualized payout of $1.85 per unit offers unitholders a 6.8% distribution yield. SmartCentres current yield is slightly below its 4-year average yield of 7.13%.

SmartCentres has a trailing twelve month FFO payout ratio of 77.7% and a trailing twelve-month AFFO payout ratio of 95.8%. The REIT’s forward AFFO payout ratio of 93.2% indicates improving cash flow available for distribution. I mention both FFO and AFFO because they provide different information. As a standardized metric, FFO is helpful to compare between different REITs. AFFO is the more useful indicator of how much cash is really available for distribution. At current levels, SmartCentres is paying out essentially all of its distributable income.

This monthly distribution of $0.15417 per unit has been flat since October 2019. While I always prefer to see a distribution that increases with the pace of inflation, in the retail REITs space, it is notable that SmartCentres has managed to maintain its distribution. During the COVID-19 pandemic, Crombie REIT (CRR.UN:CA) and RioCan REIT (REI.UN:CA) both slashed their distributions. While Crombie has resumed their payments at pre-COVID levels, RioCan’s distribution is still below its 2020 levels. Despite not being in a position to raise its distribution in recent years, SmartCentres has prudently managed their distribution levels to avoid a cut.

SmartCentres has tended to focus on its distribution as the primary mechanism of returning capital to shareholders. The REIT hasn’t initiated a unit buyback program since the expiry of its normal course issuer bid in 2022.

Risk Analysis

For the last two decades, the overhanging headline risk for retail REITs has been the tendency for online retail to supplant the need for brick and mortar square footage. While online retail growth continues, REITs including SmartCentres have adjusted their portfolio mixes to be more defensive to these pressures.

Looking at Walmart, for example, the company has made itself indispensable for in-person retail through investments in its grocery and DIY business lines. Serving as both in person retail experiences and fulfilment centres for grocery delivery, Walmart has leveraged its brick-and-mortar footprint. Shares of Walmart are up 27% over the last 12 months, compared to 21% for Amazon, a fully online retailer. In addition to Walmart, other major tenants include grocers like Loblaw Cos. Ltd. (L:CA) and Sobeys Inc. (EMP.A:CA), as well established retailers Dollarama Inc. (DOL:CA), TJX Companies Inc. (TJX), and Canadian Tire Corp. Ltd. (CTC:CA). These creditworthy tenants offer stability and defensiveness to the REIT's occupancy.

At 23% of revenue, the concentration in leased space to Walmart presents some revenue diversification risk; however, I see the quality of revenue here as outweighing the concentration risk.

Balance Sheet

SmartCentres has approximately $1.15B in available liquidity including $875M available on its operating facility and an additional $250M accordion facility. Should the company ever need to deleverage, it also has the option of divesting some of its raw land assets or tapping its large, and growing unencumbered asset pool of $9.6B.

Unchanged from the previous quarter, SmartCentres had adjusted debt to adjusted EBITDA of 9.6X for the 12-month period ending in Q2. Although 89% of debt is fixed rate, this leverage is high relative to other retail REIT peers with the subsector average at 7.7X. Peer, RioCan has a similar debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 8.96X, while Choice Properties REIT (CHP.UN:CA) is guiding leverage of below 7.5X for the year. SmartCentres debt carries a weighted average term to maturity of 3.1 years with a weighted average interest rate of 3.94%.

The Canadian retail REIT sector has been a destination for capital investment in the last year. With $3.6B in debt issued in 2024, this property subsector accounted for the largest share of capital raised, representing 71% of all debt raised in the Canadian REIT sector in 2024. This trend is supportive of the REIT's plans for additional development and suggests the capital markets could support debt financing to fund growth projects. Like other REITs, SmartCentres will benefit from further Bank of Canada interest rate cuts.

In August 2025, DBRS Morningstar, a ratings agency, reconfirmed SmartCentres credit rating at "BBB Mid rating with a Stable outlook".

Morningstar DBRS anticipates SmartCentres leverage, as measured by total debt-to-EBITDA, will improve in the high 9.0X range by YE2025, through the Trust's organic growth driven by strong occupancy levels, sustained new and existing lease renewals at higher rental rates, and income from recently completed and near-term developments. Morningstar DBRS expects EBITDA interest coverage to fluctuate at the current level, of around mid 2X range in the near-to-medium term.

The ratings agency confirmed that it would consider a ratings upgrade if SmartCentres were able to improve leverage to less than 9.2X EBITDA, while improving and maintaining interest coverage to more than 2.7X.

Investor Takeaways

Verdict

SmartCentres is an accomplished operator with an enviable track record of maintaining structurally full occupancy across its portfolio. SmartCentres has an opportunity to grow NOI through the densification of its current property portfolio, the development of its raw land. While the REIT has reasonable liquidity and has been successful in raising debt when needed, its leverage is at the high end of the sector average and may limit the capacity and magnitude of development plans.

In my previous coverage of SmartCentres in May 2023, I rated the REIT a buy on its growth potential and high-quality property base. While I continue to see SmartCentres as the highest quality operator in the Canadian retail REIT space, I am downgrading the REIT to a hold on its slow progress in deleveraging and stagnant distribution yield. While income-focused investors could add SmartCentres at current levels, unit price appreciation is likely to remain tepid as the REIT's growth is financed through debt.

While SmartCentres is a high-quality REIT offering attractive income, its elevated leverage is a concern. I would prefer to see SmartCentres prioritize deleveraging with the proceeds of any divestments. The REIT's high AFFO payout ratio makes it unlikely the distribution will be increased in the near term. SmartCentres 6.9% distribution yield is backed by quality cash flow and supported by a 22-year record of uninterrupted distribution payments.

Looking Ahead

SmartCentres is set to release its Q3 results on Wednesday, November 12, 2025. Investors will want to look for updates on the REIT's capital recycling program and how proceeds will be deployed to maximize unitholder value. Income seekers can also look for signs of an improving payout ratio that would give line of sight to the prospect of resuming distribution increases.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Robotics And Physical AI: A New Era In Automation
data.description:
This piece is one in a series that delves further into the leading themes emerging from this year’s iteration of our flagship research project, Charting Disruption.

Robotics elevates AI from the digital realm into the operating system of the physical world. As generative AI models grow more capable and associated hardware becomes cheaper and more versatile, we’re rapidly advancing into the era of physical AI, where networks of machines can think, see, move, and act in real time to augment human workflows.

This shift carries profound implications. Human labor productivity could be supercharged as people increasingly deploy robots for physical tasks. Entirely new use cases will emerge across sectors such as last-mile logistics, self-driving, and robotic manufacturing. Ultimately, this could culminate in Humanoid systems advancing, as general-purpose physical AI brings intelligent automation to everyday businesses and households. In our view, Robotics & Physical AI form a defining theme of the intelligence age.

Manufacturing’s Automation Shift Is Now an Economic Imperative

Manufacturing has long been central to robotics adoption. Global stock of industrial robots already totals roughly 4.7 million, offering automation a healthy installed base into a core sector of the economy.1 That adoption is expected to further accelerate as new priorities such as reshoring and reindustrialization take shape in strategic industries such as semiconductors and electric vehicle (EV) components.

In 2024, new global industrial robot installations reached 542,000 units, more than doubling over the past decade and marking the second-highest annual installation count of industrial robots in history.2 Asia accounted for 74% of new deployments, compared with 16% in Europe and 9% in the Americas. Annual installations are projected to rise another 6% in 2025 and surpass 700,000 units by 2028, underscoring automation’s steady advance. 3

Falling automation costs and rising labor expenses further reinforce the structural global reshoring shift. Average U.S. hourly manufacturing wages reached $34 in 2025, and are expected to rise to $39 by decades end.4 Meanwhile, the average cost of an industrial robot is expected to continue to compress, while functionalities improve.5 These dynamics enable a greater quantity and flexibility of robotic systems to operate in a wider range of settings, shifting the economic advantage in favor of automation.

Robots are also getting smarter and more flexible due to AI. Rather than the rigid, fixed setups of the past, software-defined robot platforms with standardized interfaces enable plug-and-play adaptation. This modularization reduces downtime, supports reconfiguration, and lowers integration risk. In effect, companies get the economics of mass customization. Continuous improvements in algorithms, semiconductor efficiency, and power systems are accelerating this shift.

Collaborative robots, or cobots, are also expanding the frontier of industrial automation. Designed to work safely alongside humans, they take on hazardous, repetitive, or precision tasks at a fraction of the cost, allowing workers to focus on higher-value activities such as design, supervision, and decision-making.

Robotics Is Advancing Rapidly Across Services

Improving intelligence is helping Robotics move rapidly beyond factory floors into the everyday economy, such as warehouses, hospitals, delivery networks, and retail spaces. These segments face chronic labor shortages, high turnover, and rising expectations for speed and precision, creating ideal conditions for automation to thrive.

In logistics, autonomous mobile robots now manage everything from pallet movement to last-mile sorting. Amazon alone operates over one million warehouse robots worldwide by using fleets like Proteus and Sparrow to transport and identify packages with minimal human input.6 Walmart, FedEx, and DHL are also integrating robotics to stabilize throughput and protect against labor volatility.

In healthcare, surgical robots are transforming the operating room by enhancing precision, reducing recovery times, and expanding access to complex procedures. In 2025, it’s estimated that roughly 50% of surgeons perform some type of general robotics surgery, up from just 9% in 2012.7 Intuitive Surgical’s da Vinci installed robot base has nearly doubled in the last five years, reaching 10,488 installed units in June 2025.8 Beyond the operating room, hospitals use autonomous systems for medication delivery, sanitation, and patient mobility support, freeing up nurses and technicians to focus on direct care.

In retail, robots increasingly monitor shelf inventory, restocking items, and cleaning aisles. In hospitality, autonomous butlers and delivery bots are increasingly common in hotels across Asia and the U.S., handling room service and concierge logistics. The food industry has begun to implement automated kitchen arms that assemble burgers, brew coffee, and mix drinks with precision and consistency. And in transportation, autonomous robotaxis and delivery pods travel city streets, building toward a future where goods and people move seamlessly through networks of intelligent machines. Since launching its commercial service in 2018, Waymo now handles over 250,000 driverless trips across five major U.S. cities.9

The Evolution of Physical AI Culminates in Humanoid Development

Humanoid robots are emerging as the next major frontier in physical automation, bridging the gap between industrial machinery and intelligent, adaptive assistants designed for human environments. Unlike traditional factory robots, which are fixed and specialized, humanoids walk, see, manipulate objects, and communicate naturally. They’re designed for the spaces people already inhabit, such as warehouses, hospitals, offices, and eventually homes, giving them enormous potential to address global labor shortages, support aging populations, and unlock new forms of productivity.

The market opportunity is vast. Humanoid adoption could touch roughly one-third of industrial labor roles and up to 15% of global households by the mid-2030s, translating to nearly $5 trillion in total economic potential.10 Pilots for early prototypes, such as Agility Robotics’ Digit and Figure’s humanoid models, are already underway in logistics and manufacturing.

By 2030, it’s estimated that global annual humanoid sales could reach 1 million, just 17 years after commercial humanoid sales began. By 2040, cumulative humanoid unit sales could potentially reach 400 million.11 Such a trajectory would closely parallel the early expansion of the automobile industry, which similarly took about 17 years to progress from initial commercialization to 1 million units sold.12

Conclusion: Physical Intelligence Starts to Make Its Mark

The rise of Robotics and Physical AI marks a structural transformation in the global economy, as intelligence extends from the digital realm into the physical world. Automation that once centered on manufacturing is now advancing across a wide range of industries, improving productivity, precision, and scalability. As humanoid and autonomous systems evolve, they will increasingly bridge the gap between industrial capability and human adaptability. Collectively, these developments position Robotics and Physical AI as a defining investment theme of the intelligence age – one with the potential to reshape productivity, open new markets, and drive long-term economic growth.

Footnotes

  1. IFR. (2025, September 25). Global Robot Demand in Factories Doubles Over 10 Years.
  2. Ibid.
  3. Ibid.
  4. Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis (FRED). (2025, August). Average Hourly Earnings of All Employees, Manufacturing.
  5. Global X ETFs forecast as of September 19, 2025 with information derived from: Cette, G., Spiezia, V., & Nobile, C. (2024, June 22). The Contribution of Robots to Productivity and GDP Growth in Advanced Economies Over 1960-2022. American Economic Association Conference – 2025. ACES Session: Institutions and Productivity in Advanced Countries. Klump, R., Jurkat, A., & Schneider, F. (2021, November 1). Tracking the Rise of Robots: A Survey of the IFR Database and Its Applications. MPRA Paper No. 110390. Goethe University, Frankfurt.
  6. Amazon. (2025, June 30). Amazon launches a new AI foundation model to power its robotic fleet and deploys its 1 millionth robot.
  7. Market.us Media. (2025, January 13). Robotic Surgery Statistics 2025 By – Procedures, Safety, Complications.
  8. Intuitive Surgical. (2025, July 22). Intuitive Announces Second Quarter Earnings.
  9. The Driverless Digest. (2025, October 1). Waymo Stats 2025: Funding, Growth, Coverage, Fleet Size & More.
  10. Global X ETFs. (2024, March 1). The Rise of Humanoids, Explained.
  11. Ibid.
  12. Ibid.

Information provided by Global X Management Company LLC.

Investing involves risk, including the possible loss of principal. Diversification does not ensure a profit nor guarantee against a loss.

This material represents an assessment of the market environment at a specific point in time and is not intended to be a forecast of future events, or a guarantee of future results. This information is not intended to be individual or personalized investment or tax advice and should not be used for trading purposes. Please consult a financial advisor or tax professional for more information regarding your investment and/or tax situation.

data.title: First Watch Restaurant Group Is Surprisingly Tasty
data.description:
In screening for new companies, one firm that I came across that immediately popped out was First Watch Restaurant Group (FWRG). For those not familiar with the enterprise, it operates as a ‘daytime dining’ a company that serves customers made-to-order breakfasts, brunches, and lunches. The reason why the company jumped out was because one of its locations is actually quite close to my house and because I have eaten from it on multiple occasions. So naturally, as a foodie and an investor, I would want to dig in more. What I found is a vibrant company that's growing at a rapid pace. Often, these types of firms have a tendency to be expensive. But not this one. In fact, based on my own estimates that I believe to be relatively conservative, I would argue that it offers market beating potential moving forward. As such, I have no problem rating it a ‘buy’ at this time.

However, I do think that one thing that investors should be mindful of is that earnings are coming up soon. Before the market opens on November 4th, management should be serving up financial results covering the third quarter of the company's 2025 fiscal year. Leading up to that point, revenue and profits are both forecasted to rise nicely. But in this uncertain economic climate, investors would be wise to keep a close eye on matters.

Digging Into First Watch Restaurant Group

As I mentioned already, First Watch Restaurant Group is a daytime dining firm that is focused on preparing for its customers made-to-order breakfasts, brunches, and lunches. In my head, I fit it into the same category as a Bob Evans or Denny's (DENN). However, this firm is unique in that its locations are typically only open for 7.5 hours a day. You would think that such restrictive hours would make it hard for the locations that it has to perform well. But even with this, the average restaurant generates around $2.2 million worth of revenue each year.

The company makes itself stand out in a couple of ways. For starters, management makes sure to keep their menu fresh. In the second quarter of this year, for instance, some of the items that it had on its menu included bacon cheddar cornbread, wild berry lavender French toast, a bacon, egg, and cheddar sandwich, and pineapple beverages. Other examples would be its blueberry lemon cornbread, shrimp and grits, and more. This menu is then supercharged through the use of fresh and quality ingredients. I don't know about you, but the number of times I have been to a restaurant that did not take that simple and obvious principle to heart, has been astronomical.

In recent years, management has achieved remarkable growth. Back in 2022, revenue stood at $730.2 million. Last year, sales had grown to $1.02 billion. This growth was driven largely by an increase in the number of locations that the firm has in operation. They grew from 474 to 572 over this window of time. However, this growth is a bit deceptive. During that three-year window, the number of franchised locations actually contracted from 108 to 83. And the number of company-owned restaurants jumped from 366 to 489. By shifting away from franchised locations and toward company-owned ones, management is able to capture more revenue and to better control the quality of the experience for customers. The downside to this, however, is that there is a risk of lower margins. But by prioritizing scaling at the rest strong level, management likely hopes to offset this.

Same restaurant sales have also increased, but this picture is more nuanced. 2022 saw an increase of 14.5% on a same restaurant basis. This is almost certainly because of the economy recovering after the COVID-19 pandemic. There was another 7.6% increase in 2023, though in 2024 there was a decline of 0.5% as traffic fell 4%. I do know that consumers are becoming increasingly constrained from a financial standpoint. And the fact of the matter is that eating out is practically always more expensive than eating at home. The good news is that this year, things are looking up. But before we touch on that, I do think touching on bottom line performance for the company is appropriate also.

The first chart in this article shows that, as revenue for the institution grew, so too did profitability. This included net income, operating cash flow, adjusted operating cash flow that essentially just strips out changes in working capital, and EBITDA. In the chart above, you can see that, while this year the firm is seeing some downside from a margin perspective, the restaurant level total profit margin that the company has exhibited has increased as it has grown. This further validates my previous statement regarding the firm's motivation to shift more and more toward an ownership approach to its expansion as opposed to a franchise-based one.

For this year, revenue for the company continues to expand. Sales during the first half of 2025 amounted to $590.1 million. That's up 17.8% compared to the $501 million the company reported last year. Some of this was because of a 2.1% increase in same restaurant sales. But the vast majority came from a jump in the number of restaurants from 538 to 600. This came at a time when the number of franchised locations declined from 79 to 69, and was driven by a surge in the number of company-owned locations from 459 to 531.

When it comes to this year, management expects the total number of net new restaurants to increase by between 59 and 64. Between 7 and 9 of these will be franchised locations. But mostly, the company is adding between 55 and 58 company owned restaurants. This should help to propel EBITDA to between $119 million and $123 million. But as I mentioned already, this year the firm has suffered from some margin contraction. While some of this is because of higher labor and other related expenses, a lot of it seems to come from a rise in food and beverage costs. Management blamed this on new restaurants that it acquired, and the lower margins they typically result in, as well as commodity inflation and the firm's decision to shift toward a meat heavy menu. So we are going to see some profit increase, but as the chart that shows financial results for the first half of this year demonstrates, profitability as a percentage of revenue is certainly going to decline.

In the chart above, you can see how shares of the company are currently priced using estimates for 2025 and historical results for 2024. Honestly, these are multiples that would typically fit near the very low end of the fair value range in my book. But as you will see shortly, I am a bit more optimistic about what the future might hold. That tilts things in the favor of a soft ‘buy’ instead.

One thing that I will mention is that management remains committed to continuing to grow the number of locations that the company has. This is because the economics of growth makes sense here. According to management, the typical build-out cost of a single location is $1.75 million. But over the ensuing three years, the average revenue achieved by these locations is around $2.7 million. And given the 18% to 20% restaurant level operating margin, we get an internal rate of return of around 18% or greater for each store. That's why management is dedicated this year to spending $148 million to $152 million on capital projects, with most of that focused on growth.

Projecting into the future is always fraught with uncertainty. But by using some reasonable assumptions, such as the firm's target of a 3.5% same store sales increase each year, the same margins that the company exhibited last year since I suspect it will be able to eventually return to those levels thanks to scalability and raising its prices to offset higher costs, and by using some other reasonable estimates, I was able to create the table below. In it, you can see how much the company could expand if it decides not to take on any additional debt and uses all excess capital toward growth.

Assuming this ends up being the case, we can see how, by the year 2030, the company could grow to generate $2.16 billion in revenue, with system wide sales of about $2.47 billion. If we use these as base level estimates for the future, we can then see in the chart below how much annual upside the company should exhibit if it trades at the same multiples that it's trading for today. Considering that the S&P 500 typically averages between 10% and 11% annually, I would consider these potential returns to justify a bullish outlook.

Of course, anything can change as new data comes in. It just so happens that, before the market opens on November 4th, management will be announcing financial results for the third quarter of the 2025 fiscal year. Analysts currently expect revenue to come in at $309.3 million, which would be up 22.9% compared to the $251.6 million the company reported a year earlier. They also expect earnings per share to grow from $0.03 to $0.07, which would take net profits up from $2.1 million to $4.4 million. As the table below illustrates, the firm did generate positive cash flow in the third quarter of last year. And I would venture to say that if revenue and profits do increase this year, these cash flow metrics will grow also.

Takeaway

Based on all the data currently available, I would say that First Watch Restaurant Group justifies a bullish outlook. Management is actively working to grow the business, and the overall trajectory that it has been on is impressive. My own analysis, which assumes management does not lever up in order to grow more rapidly, seems to show conservatively that upside is likely to exceed what the broader market would enjoy. And with analysts optimistic as well, I have no reason not to be myself. Because of this, I believe that assigning it a 'buy' rating is the right choice.

data.title: An Asset-Heavy Model, A Return-Light Result: The FRP Holdings Sell Thesis (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
FRP Holdings, Inc. (FRPH)’s shareholders have experienced five years of profound disappointment as the share price has starkly underperformed. While broad market indices have soared, delivering total returns in excess of 110%, FRP's share price has crawled forward a mere 11.11%, offering no dividend to compensate for its relative stagnation. This is the result of its asset-heavy business model that leads to poor returns, a concerning decline in profitability despite revenue growth, and a valuation that is excessive compared to its sector. As a result, I give the company a “Sell” rating.

A Half-Decade of Underperformance

For investors in FRP, the last five years have been a period to forget. In that time, the company’s share price has risen by just 11.11% compared to 99.12% for the iShares Russell 3000 ETF (IWV) and 105.26% for the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY). Given that the firm does not pay out dividends, the total return picture is even worse, with IWV having total returns of 112.14% and the SPY having total returns of 120.23%.

In the year-to-date, the company’s shares are down 24.42% while the IWV’s total returns are 17.49% and the SPY’s are 18.31%.

A Real Estate Firm

FRP is a holding company that seeks to improve shareholder value by actively investing in and managing real estate through its subsidiaries, FRP Development Corp. and Florida Rock Properties, Inc. It describes its business segments as:

“(i) leasing and management of industrial and commercial properties (the “Industrial and Commercial Segment”), (ii) leasing and management of mining royalty land owned by the Company (the “Mining Royalty Lands Segment”), (iii) real property acquisition, entitlement, development and construction primarily for multifamily, industrial and commercial, or residential either alone or through joint ventures (the “Development Segment”), (iv) ownership, leasing and management of apartment buildings through joint ventures (the “Multifamily Segment”)”

The company endeavours to increase asset value and net operating income (NOI) growth, using profits from these activities and disposals to invest in the industry, in multifamily, industrial, and commercial, and mining and royalties assets, either through strategic partnerships or alone. These assets are held for long-run capital appreciation or for opportunistic sale.

The Industrial and Commercial Segment owns, leases, and manages ten warehouses, four different locations, two ground leases, and an office building FRP partly occupies. In Q2 2025, the segment’s net operating income (NOI) declined by $177,000 to $1.01 million after a tenant failed to pay rent and had to be evicted. In the year-to-date (YTD), NOI is down $197,000 to $2.15 million, due to the tenant eviction. In the CEO’s letter to the shareholders in 2024, he spoke of the firm having, “completed 100% industrial occupancy of 247,340 square feet in three new warehouses, and purchased land for another 1,281,420 square feet”. This suggests that in the YTD, industrial occupancy is a little under 100%.

The firm’s Mining Royalty Lands Segment owns around 16,648 acres of properties that are leased for rents and royalties purposes, and 4,280 acres as part of a Brooksville joint venture with Vulcan Materials Company (VMC). Of these assets, only one is in Virginia, and the rest are in Florida and Georgia. In Q2 2025, the segment’s NOI increased by 21% to $3.67 million as royalty payments and unrealized revenues recovered from the year prior. In the YTD, NOI increased by 20% to $6.95 million due to a recovery in royalty payments and unrealized revenue.

FRP’s Development Segment owns and monitors its development land and seeks to convert it from non-income-producing to income-producing by building income generating assets such as apartments, or selling them or doing a joint venture. The segment also acquires attractive parcels of land for development or sale.

The Multifamily Segment owns, leases and manages multifamily properties, two of which are consolidated joint ventures, Dock 79 and The Maren, and four are consolidated joint ventures, either alone or through joint ventures, Bryant Street, Riverside,.408 Jackson, and The Verge. Development Segment properties that are built up are transferred to this segment when some threshold occupancy rate is achieved. In Q2 2025, pro rata NOI rose by 1% to $4.74 million, while in the YTD, it increased by 2% to $9.37 million.

One thing is clear: the business model is asset-heavy, and so, at a minimum, returns will be very low, given the capital that is needed to fund expansion.

Betting on the Bakers

FRP’s executive chairman and former CEO, John D. Baker II owns around 17.5% of the company, while members of his family own 17.8% of the company, and his son, John D. Baker III serves as the current CEO. This means that the Bakers have a lot of influence in the Board of Directors and in the running of the company. Investors have to trust that the interests of the Bakers are aligned with theirs.

Declining Profitability

Since 2020, the company’s revenue has grown from $17.89 million to $32.29 million in the trailing twelve months (TTM). However, the firm’s profitability has declined since then, from $12.72 million to $5.33 million. The firm’s margins have been poor. While operating margin has risen from -3.11% in 2020 to -0.13% in the TTM, they still show that the business’ core operations are not generating a profit. Profit margins have declined from 71.06% in 2020 to 16.5% in the TTM. The company only started measuring NOI in 2021? and that has grown from $17.6 million to $39.39 million. Baker III has guided for flat NOI in full-year 2025, saying,

“that level of growth, while remarkable, is also unsustainable.

Due to the timing of construction, delivery, and investment, we expect NOI in 2025 to remain flat if not slightly off of 2024. In the Industrial and Commercial Segment, 53% of the platform will be vacant and up for renewal. These vacancies at Cranberry and at our new Chelsea building will take time to lease-up and will have operating expenses that will eat into 2025 NOI when compared to 2024. The lease-up of three different projects (Verge, Bryant Street, and .408 Jackson) in our Multifamily segment was a huge driver of 2024 NOI growth. The rapid NOI growth we experienced with the lease-ups will give way in 2025 to more organic growth as we grow rents on already stabilized assets, a particular challenge for the DC assets which will be competing with a glut of new projects. Mining royalties should remain strong in 2025, though from an NOI perspective, it will be difficult to keep pace with 2024, simply for the fact that we received a considerable back dated minimum payment at one location, which we can’t replicate for obvious reasons.”

That also seems to imply that net income will also be flat or down from 2024 levels. The firm’s efficiency levels are poor: returns on assets (ROA) have risen from -0.07% to -0.00%, and return on equity (ROE) has declined from 3.03% to 1.17%. This is to be expected: the business model is asset heavy, so returns even at the best of times are likely to be low. That they are negative suggests that the company does not have the ability to extract more income from its value chain. Returns are likely to decline further: Baker III spoke of 2025 as “year zero” of FRP’s industrial growth strategy, outlining plans to, “build three new industrial projects every two years for the foreseeable future and look to double the size of our industrial platform over the next five years”. These investments may pay off in future, but, in the interim, they will erode returns.

Valuation Has Downsides

At the current price, FRP has a price/earnings (P/E) multiple of 82.29, compared to an average of 106.52 for its peers, IRSA Inversiones y Representaciones Sociedad Anónima (IRS), Corporación Inmobiliaria Vesta, S.A.B. de C.V. (VTMX), and LandBridge Company LLC (LB) and Aswath Damodaran’s sector median of 38.85. if we assume that the company’s diluted earnings per share (EPS) are constant, at $0.28, and that FRP’s share price converges on its sector and peer averages, then, there are significant downsides in the current share price. As the table below shows, the company’s share price could decline by over 12%, leading to a target price of $20.35.

Price/Earnings Multiple Source

Target Price = Earnings per Share Estimate × Price/Earnings

Upside/(Downside) from $23.15

Damodaran

$ 10.88

-53.01%

Peers

$ 29.83

Equally Weighted Target

-12.09%

Source: Damodaran, Seeking Alpha, and author calculations

Management’s own analysis, using a sum-of-the-parts analysis, suggests a fair value of between $27.91 and $31.14 per share, compared to a current price of $23.15.

Even if correct, the lower bound gives very little margin of safety, making the firm at least “neutral” on a range of attractiveness.

Conclusion

FRP’s capital-intensive, real estate development model, has consistently failed to translate asset growth into total shareholder returns. This is clear from its declining net income, negative operating margins, and abysmal ROA and ROE, all of which signal a business struggling to profit from its operations. Furthermore, its current valuation, with a P/E ratio of 82.29, carries significant downsides. Management's own guidance for flat NOI in 2025, coupled with the significant capital required to execute its "year zero" industrial expansion plan, promises continued pressure on profitability and returns for the foreseeable future. As a result, the company’s share price is likely to continue to fare badly and I assign the stock a “Sell” rating.

data.title: Introducing Charting Disruption: Outlook For 2026 And Beyond
data.description:
Innovation remains one of the most persistent drivers of long-term growth – reshaping industries, creating new markets, and sustaining momentum through economic cycles. Yet, identifying trends alone is no longer sufficient. Investors must recognize how themes intersect and reinforce one another, as breakthroughs increasingly emerge from the convergence of technologies, infrastructure, and resources rather than from any single trend.

Artificial intelligence (AI) may be the most visible catalyst of this transformation, but it is far from the only one. Advances in semiconductors, data centers, electrification, and energy systems are powering progress across robotics, defense, and healthtech – forming an interconnected innovation ecosystem that underpins modern growth.

Adoption is also accelerating. Each technological wave reaches scale faster than the last, compressing what once took decades into years. Globalization, automation, and data infrastructure have shortened the path from discovery to application, blurring traditional industry boundaries and amplifying innovation’s ripple effects across the economy.

For investors, this speed and interdependence redefine the opportunity set. Understanding where innovation originates – and how its impact compounds across sectors – has become essential to positioning for the next era of thematic growth. Charting Disruption 2026 explores that evolution, quantifying how convergence is reshaping markets and revealing where tomorrow’s structural opportunities may emerge.

Charting the Path Forward

The architecture of innovation is both interconnected and compounding. Each stage – from the materials that power production to the applications transforming industries – builds on the one before it, creating a continuous cycle of progress. Understanding how these forces interact offers a clearer view of where disruption begins, how it scales, and where tomorrow’s opportunities may emerge.

Exhaustible Resources: Securing the Foundations of Innovation

Technological progress begins with access to finite materials that power production, electrification, and the infrastructure on which modern economies depend.

  • Copper, also known as the "metal of electrification," is seeing a sharp rise in demand due to its high electrical conductivity and malleability, perfect for use in medical devices and EVs, as well as solar and wind energy.1
  • Due to their use in EVs – not to mention smartphones, laptops, power tools, and cameras – the demand for lithium-ion batteries is projected to grow seven-fold between 2022 and 2030.2
  • Permanent magnets accounted for 42.5% of rare earth element demand in 2023 for their use in electronics, such as cell phones, and clean energy systems, such as fuel cells.3
  • Silver’s high electrical conductivity, strong thermal conductivity, antimicrobial properties, and ability to reflect 95-99% of visible light makes it critical to industrial applications such as solar panels.4
  • Using AI to help generate a 100-word email uses just over one bottle of water.5
  • Less than ten pellets of uranium fuel – approximately the weight of 10 AA batteries – can power the average household for a year.6

Sustaining technological progress depends not only on discovery but on the reliable availability of the materials that make it possible. As demand for copper, lithium, uranium, and rare earths accelerates alongside electrification and automation, ensuring access to these essential inputs is critical to maintaining momentum. Efficient production, responsible sourcing, and advances in recycling and substitution will all play a role in preventing material scarcity from becoming a bottleneck to innovation.

Structural Needs: Building the Infrastructure for Growth

As global demand for energy, connectivity, and production capacity accelerates, the world’s physical and organizational systems are under pressure to expand, modernize, and sustain long-term growth.

  • Global fragmentation, aging infrastructure assets, shifting demographics, climate change, and the rise of disruptive technologies are driving an urgent need for as much as $106 trillion in infrastructure investment through 2040.7
  • By 2035, projections anticipate data center electricity consumption at 1,596 TWh, positioning their demand between the 2024 usage levels of Russia (1,193 TWh) and India (2,027 TWh).8,9
  • Nuclear power represents a potential fuel source with a low average CO2 life cycle, low land footprint, and one of the highest uptime rates of any energy source.10
  • Achieving national energy ambitions will require adding or upgrading around 80 million kilometers of power grids by 2040, the equivalent of rebuilding the entire existing global power network.11

The modernization of infrastructure is no longer a long-term aspiration but an economic imperative. Trillions in investment will be required to replace aging assets, expand grid capacity, and build the physical backbone for a more digital, electrified, and interconnected world. These structural systems – spanning transportation, manufacturing, and energy – serve as the bridge between physical resources and technological progress. Their evolution will dictate how efficiently economies can adapt to disruption, support innovation, and sustain resilience in an era defined by accelerated change.

Enabling Technologies: Powering the Digital Core

Digital and computational systems such as semiconductors, data centers, and cloud infrastructure provide the backbone for automation, scalability, and innovation across industries.

  • Surge in accelerated computing is compelling chipmakers and equipment suppliers to ramp and retool for sub-5 nm semiconductor production, critical for producing next-gen processing hardware. By 2030, nearly $500 billion could be spent annually on AI chips, driving at least half a trillion in semi manufacturing CapEx.12
  • To meet the anticipated 2030 global data center demand, projections estimate an investment need of nearly $7 trillion – $5.2 trillion for facilities supporting AI processing and $1.5 trillion for traditional IT applications.13
  • Propelled by rapid advances in smaller, more efficient models, the cost of running inference at GPT-3.5 performance levels fell more than 280-fold between November 2022 and October 2024, as hardware expenses declined by roughly 30% per year and energy efficiency improved by about 40% annually.14
  • Global cloud infrastructure spending is projected to surpass $400 billion in 2025, with approximately 60% of the market captured by Amazon Web Services (30%), Microsoft’s Azure (20%), and Google Cloud (13%).15
  • Cybersecurity remains a top priority for businesses and individuals, as the Federal Bureau of Investigation revealed over $16 billion in losses due to cybercrime in 2024, up 33% from 2023.16

The surge in computing power, connectivity, and automation underscores a new phase of efficiency and intelligence across industries. From semiconductors to cloud networks, technological capacity is compounding – reducing costs, expanding scale, and transforming what’s possible. As innovation accelerates, these enabling systems no longer function as support infrastructure alone; they have become the engines of transformation themselves. Their continued advancement will shape how effectively new applications emerge, connect, and redefine the modern economy.

Applications: Turning Innovation into Impact

Innovation ultimately finds meaning through real-world use – transforming ideas into solutions that redefine industries, improve lives, and drive global growth.

  • In addition to success rates between 94% and 100%, robot-assisted surgeries may offer several patient benefits, including reduced postoperative discomfort, lower likelihood of infection, minimized blood loss, shortened hospital recovery times, and less visible scarring.17
  • Cheap and adaptable drones offer significant economic advantages in warfare over traditional tanks, costing 25,000 times less, reducing time to build by 4,380 times, and offering 50,000 times the production capacity.18,19,20
  • Global EV sales surpassed 17 million units in 2024, pushing their share of the global car market above 20% for the first time.21 With affordability improving across regions, EVs are on track to exceed a 40% market share by 2030.22
  • Currently, drugs take about 10-15 years and $1.8 billion to develop, while just 10% of investigational treatments gain approval, but AI can help reduce pre-clinical delays and lower costs by up to 50%.23,24,25,26
  • GLP-1 therapies continue to demonstrate strong potential for weight management and a wide range of other health applications, contributing to projected revenues of $183 billion by 2032.27

As these innovations mature, their influence extends beyond individual sectors – shaping productivity, resilience, and global competitiveness. What once marked the frontier of technology is rapidly becoming the foundation of a new economic paradigm, where investing in innovation means investing in the long-term transformation of everyday life.

Conclusion

The interplay between technological innovation and macroeconomic transformation is reshaping how growth emerges and where opportunity concentrates. Thematic investing offers a framework for capturing this evolution – identifying the structural forces, from digitalization to decarbonization, that transcend sectors and market cycles. By looking beyond traditional classifications, investors can better position for the convergence of trends driving the global economy forward. Innovation may be unpredictable in form, but its trajectory – toward deeper integration, greater efficiency, and expanding impact – remains unmistakably clear.
