data.title: UTG Vs. UTF: More Reasons To Go With UTF Amid Lower Rates
data.description:
UTG and UTF: previous thesis and new developments

My last analysis on Cohen & Steers Infrastructure Fund (UTF) was published on July 22 in an article titled "XLU Vs. UTF: We Prefer A Leveraged Utility Play Amid 'Build, Baby, Build'". That article focused on the potential policy shift towards infrastructure buildout and rated UTF as a BUY. For the Reaves Utility Income Trust (NYSE:UTG) CEF, I last covered it on Aug 11 with an article titled "UTG: Let Your Profit Run Amid 'Build, Baby, Build'". I rated UTG as a HOLD after balancing the upside risks from the same potential policy shift and the valuation risks judging by its below-average dividend yield.

Since then, a few new catalysts have surfaced both in terms of macroeconomic conditions and also fund-specific changes. In the remainder of this article, I will detail the most important catalyst in each category on my list: the change in interest rates and also the relative valuation changes of UTG and UTF. After examining these changes, my conclusion is that UTF provides a better return/risk curve than UTG due to A) its more aggressive use of leverage and B) its sizable valuation discount relative to UTG.

Let me start with the changes in interest rates. I assume you already know that the Federal Reserve has just announced another cut of 25 basis points early this week. The cut was widely expected by the market a while before the Fed made the official announcement, as you can tell from the chart below. Wednesday. To be more specific, the chart below displays the 10-Year Treasury Rate (I:10YTR) and the 3-Month Treasury Rate (I:3MTRNK) in the past year. As seen, both long- and short-term treasury yields have been trending downward since my last writings (i.e., around the July to Aug timeframe). After the Fed rate cut was officially announced, both 10-Year and 3-month treasury rates dropped further to ~4.0% and ~3.9%, both hovering near the 52-week low.

Looking ahead, the market expects dominant odds for another 25 basis point cut by the end of 2025 per data provided by CME Group FedWatch Tool (see the second chart below). Amid such a trend of decreasing rates, I feel it's a good time to bet more aggressively on the utility sector, and UTF is the fund that uses more leverage than UTG as detailed next.

UTG and UTF CEFs: basic information and exposure

Before moving onto further specifics, I feel this is a good place to cover some basics for both CEFs in case there are investors unfamiliar with them. Both funds are popular CEFs for investors seeking concentrated exposure to utility/infrastructure stocks, and their specific investment strategies are quoted below. Both funds have a long history (both incepted in 2004) and feature similarly sizable AUM of around $2.5B to $3.5B. Notionally, UTF has a slightly higher expense ratio of 2.29% compared to UTG's 2.23%, as shown in the chart below. However, the comparison of fees is complicated by their differences in leverages and borrowing costs, which I will revisit in a minute.

UTG fund description: The Fund's investment objective is to provide a high level of after-tax income and total return consisting primarily of tax-advantaged dividend income and capital appreciation. The Fund pursues its investment objective by investing at least 80% of its total assets in the securities of domestic and foreign companies involved to a significant extent in providing products, services or equipment for (i) the generation or distribution of electricity, gas or water, (ii) telecommunications activities or (iii) infrastructure operations, such as airports, toll roads and municipal services.

UTF fund description: The Funds objective is to achieve total return, with an emphasis on income. Under normal market conditions, the Fund will invest at least 80% of its managed assets in securities issued by infrastructure companies, which consist of utilities, pipelines, toll roads, airports, railroads, ports, telecommunications companies and other infrastructure companies.

Even though both funds allocated the majority (~80% per their fund description above) toward utility/infrastructure stocks, UTG and UTF's geographic exposures are very different, as shown in the next chart. UTG's portfolio is heavily concentrated in the US, with a 108% weight (which exceeds 100% due to leverage). Ex-US exposure is minimal in the UTG funds, with Canada, the largest overseas exposure, representing 5.75% of exposure. In contrast, UTF is more geared toward ex-US exposure, with its US holdings representing less than ½ of its total assets (at a weight of 45.6%).

As detailed in my earlier articles, I feel more bullish towards domestic utility/infrastructure stocks given my anticipation of the policy shift in the US. However, as to be argued next, I believe UTF's use of leverage and valuation discount could make this up.

UTG and UTF CEF: leverage in focus

The next table compares the capital structure for UTG and UTF as of their latest fund disclosures dated on 10/30/2025. As seen, UTF's effective leverage is around 30%, substantially higher than UTG's ~17%. UTF's total debt (which is also its regulatory leverage) currently stands at $1,050 million, compared to $710 million for UTG.

With above information, now we can also take a closer look at their fees. As shown in the table below, the fee structures for UTF and UTG are quite different. In terms of headline annual expense ratios, UTF has a substantially higher total expense ratio of 3.86%, 1.43% above UTG's total expense ratio of 2.43%. However, a closer look reveals that this difference is mostly driven by higher interest expenses, where UTF is charged with a 2.47% interest expense compared to 1.49% for UTG. This is a difference of almost 1%. As such, with the market's expectation of lower interest rates ahead, I expect this to translate into a larger reduction in leverage cost for UTF than UTG, which in turn should help boost UTF's valuation and profits more substantially than UTG.

UTG and UTF CEF: yield and valuation

Speaking of valuation, UTF is also currently valued at a sizable discount relative to UTG, judging by their dividend yield spread. To wit, the next chart illustrates the historical dividend yield spread (YSF) between UTF and UTG since their inception. The spread is calculated as UTF's TTM yield minus that of UTG. As seen, the YS has exhibited some volatility over the years, but has fluctuated closely around a long-term average of 0.944%, a reflection of the stability embedded in utility/infrastructure stocks. The current YS is 1.593% as seen, notably higher than the historical average and indicating UTF's favorable valuation relative to UTG.

Other risks and final thoughts

UTF's valuation discount is also reflected in a vertical comparison, as shown in the last chart below. UTF currently provides a TTM Dividend Yield of 7.88%, which is slightly above its 4-year average yield of 7.75% (by about 2%) and indicates a slight valuation discount. In contrast, UTG has a TTM Dividend Yield of 6.05%, which is significantly below its 4-year average yield of 7.56% by about 20% and indicates a sizable valuation premium.

Of course, UTG is a solid fund in its own right too (and after all, I am rating it as a hold, not a sell). The fund offers concentrated - and also leveraged - bets on domestic stocks in a sector where I expect policy tailwinds for the next few years. UTG also features lower fees, with interest expenses excluded, than UTF. If you recall from an earlier chart, UTF's Management Fees are 1.20%, notably higher than UTG's 0.71% (although UTF's other expenses are 0.19%, slightly below the 0.23% charged by UTG).

All told, this comparison between UTF and UTG is largely motivated by two recent changes: the changes in interest rates and also fund-specific changes. Changes in the first category made me favor a fund with more leverage, and changes in the second category made UTF's valuation very attractive compared to UTG. My verdict is that these considerations should be sufficient to overcome UTF's fee drag and lower US exposure, resulting in a more favorable return/risk ratio than UTG.

data.title: Could AI Investments Backfire In 2026?
data.description:
By Mike Larson

Is the AI-fueled rally about to peak, or are we still in the early innings of a historic market transformation? In this episode of the MoneyShow MoneyMasters Podcast, Ed Clissold, Chief US Strategist at Ned Davis Research, pulls back the curtain on what’s really powering the markets as 2025 winds down.

Transcript

Mike Larson: Are all those AI companies making all those AI deals about to fly off the proverbial hamster wheel, or does this artificial intelligence CapEx boom still have room to run? Is Fed policy going to remain friendly to markets well into 2026, or could we be in store for a monetary policy surprise next year? And what about jobs? Amazon, UPS, JPMorgan Chase, they're all laying off thousands and thousands of workers or making do with less because they can, thanks to AI.

I brought an all-new guest on the MoneyShow MoneyMasters Podcast to unspool it all and explain what these key market developments mean for investors like you. His name is Ed Clissold, and he is Chief U.S. Strategist at Ned Davis Research. Ed, welcome to the podcast.

Ed, thank you so much for joining me. I know there's a lot going on in the markets, and I want to get right to that in a minute, but since I haven't had you on the podcast before, can you talk a little bit about what your background is and what you do there at Ned Davis?

Ed Clissold: Sure. So, I've been at NDR for 22 years. I was actually a client of NDR at a regional brokerage firm in Nashville, Tennessee, called J.C. Bradford. For those of you who've been around a while, maybe you've heard of it. That's also where Ned was before he founded NDR. So, that was my connection to the company, and this was in the late '90s when the screens were green every day. And you had this guy saying, it's going on for a while, but this isn't how the world really works. Eventually, you're going to pay for it.

So, I came out of business school ’02. By that point, the bubble had burst and no one wanted to hire anybody, but there's Ned Davis Research because they were growing because they had the foresight, and Ned had the foresight. So, I've been in NDR since then. I worked on the global team for a while, but for the last dozen years or so, I've been the U.S. Strategist, focused on U.S. asset allocation, styles, S&P, sector calls, things of that nature.

Mike Larson: Perfect. Well, appreciate the background. Kind of sets the stage a little bit there. I mean, as we're talking, S&P markets hitting new highs again after a little bit of turbulence in October. It's been quite the run. Where do you see markets as we get into here, deeper into the fourth quarter?

Ed Clissold: Look. If you get closer to the end of the year, the momentum trade seems to take hold. And I think it applies this year. Some years, it doesn't, but particularly what we've noticed is that there still is a swath of investors who haven't completely gotten back in after the shock of the post Liberation Day meltdown. Most people got it back into some extent, but maybe not fully invested or there's certain hedge fund investors who maybe aren't levered as they had been previously, and so you're going to see some performance chasing, but it's beyond that.

I think the number one thing is that companies have blown estimates out of the water. Some of this is because the analyst community overthought on the downside. And if you can nail it to one thing, it's that they overestimated the impact of tariffs on profit margin, missing how much had been imported beforehand. Well, I think maybe the public was taken aback maybe perhaps by the shock that a lot of the companies playing for it pretty well, but also, if you think about, like, the input cost for companies, or for some companies, what they're importing, their materials are important.

What's the biggest input for most companies? People. Yeah. So, that's part of the reason why I think you've seen hiring slowdown is that companies are perhaps you say, we're not going to hire as many people or somebody leaves. We're just not going to replace them. And so, you're not seeing as many layoffs as you would see as you're going into recession, but you're seeing some of them.

And so, corporate America has just done a great job, and then you throw on the fact that the Fed is poised to – we're recording this on Tuesday. The Fed's going to announce tomorrow. Pretty high likelihood, they're going to cut again. So, friendly Fed, subdued sentiment, good momentum, strong earnings, pretty good backdrop for stock to do fairly well.

Mike Larson: Yeah. Let's talk about the labor issue first of all because, I mean, obviously, the big news this week, Amazon, depending on what media report you look at, anywhere from 14,000 to 30,000 white-collar-type jobs. They're looking at maybe trimming. UPS, blew out the numbers, but a big part of that was, as you mentioned, cuts; thirty-some-odd thousand cuts that they've implemented as part of cost-cutting. Do you think we ever get to a point where that's going to be an issue for Wall Street, or is that more of a Main Street economic issue? And how serious of one going forward?

Ed Clissold: Yeah. So, first of all, it gets you the K-shaped recovery of the economy, where the high-end consumer is doing really well. And that is the big engine of growth for consumer spending in the U.S. economy, but at some point, it could be too much for the economy to bear, but what -- I think there's a couple of things going on. In the case of -- I don't get into individual companies, but maybe through some of the huge tech companies that hired so much during and right after COVID, there probably still is some normalization of labor force that needs to take place, but others are not.

And what we've seen in particular is the labor force participation rate, which is a mouthful economic term, but it's just who's working and who's looking to work, employed, unemployed. For young workers, 16 to 24, has dropped 2 percentage points year to date. Now, that's a volatile group. They're more sensitive. So, when the economy is slowing, they're going to feel the pinch first, but that's still a pretty big drop. And you've seen that in particular in recent computer science grads.

So, these poor kids were told to program, and they slogged through four years of programming. Maybe they could have a lot more fun if they are humanities majors and gotten a job, but they didn't. And so, now they're struggling. So, I do think there is something afoot with the economy where companies feel like they can cut some slack, and they expect to be employing AI tools going forward.

And you've seen this in tech. Heard Jamie Dimon talk about that, where they've gotten their AI tool to put together pitch decks that would take a team of junior investment bankers, days to put together, they can put together in a few minutes. I think that is coming. My view in the long run is that the economy will right size itself and will find productive use of that labor. Meantime, it can be, certainly concerning for the people going through it directly, in and of itself probably not enough to cause a recession, but it probably part of why the Fed needs to consider lowering rates in a time when inflation is still sizably above its target.

So, put it in the something to be a little worried about category. Wouldn't put it in the time-to-panic zone. For example, we have our recession watch report. There're 10 different indicators in that. We need 6 out of 10 to say you're high risk of recession. Right now there's only one in the recession risk zone. That's ISM services, but unemployment claims, CEO confidence, consumer confidence all well away from where you'd say historically, well, the economy is probably going into recession.

Mike Larson: Got it. So, let's pivot to policy on the assumption the Fed will have cut 25 basis points by the time this airs. Moving forward, what are you looking for? One more meeting in 2025, and then as we roll into 2026, what is your general Fed outlook?

Ed Clissold: Yeah. I think there's a decent chance they'll cut again in December and then probably a time in early 2026. So, friendly for now, and we've studied it when you had a Fed pause, like, we've had so they cut. They pause for at least six months, and then they resume cutting. That's what happened. They cut in December, waited nine months, cut again in September. The market tends to rally, starting three, four months before the cut, which roughly would happen this time, but I find this interesting. History doesn't repeat, it rhymes, and the fact that there's some consternation around inflation, albeit tariff-induced, right about the time you normally get that during the Fed pauses, and then the rally happened again about the time you would get that.

Going forward, the rally continues on average, although not quite as strong a pace as it did a few months leading into those Fed cuts. My concern, though, Mike, as we head into next year, is what happens in May. We're going to get a new Fed Chair, and sounds like they may announce the person early. Usually, it's two or three months before we’re in. They're talking about doing it before the end of the year. We'll see. I also think perhaps Trump, he's a master of suspense. Whether you like him or not, he's excellent at this stuff. He may keep that drawn out for longer. But regardless, we're going to get a new Fed Chair. This person is going to know the assignments, which is to keep lowering rates. But by May, if you get another two or more cuts, the Fed's going to be close to neutral. And so, that's going to be a pretty tough decision, I think, for the new Fed Chair.

Do you keep cutting on the expectation that inflation is going to come down and those cuts will be justified? In which case, then, the market may come into play. Do you start seeing inflation expectations rise? Do you start seeing the yield curve steepen more? Do you see credit spreads widen? All these things would suggest that maybe the Fed's making a policy mistake.

Now, the new Fed Chair could also come on and say, "Thank you, Mister President, I appreciate the nomination, but now that I'm confirmed, my duty is to the economy. I have a dual mandate," and that person can then just live with the Truth Social post just like Powell did. Probably not how it's going to go, but it's possible.

There's a derivation of that, or maybe the FOMC. Remember, this isn't just one person making the call. The FOMC could push back. You have to see how that would go. There's lots of ways. But the final thing is, maybe everything does work out. Inflation goes down. Fed cuts. Everybody's happy. I think that's probably unlikely, but the point is, right now, we have some pretty friendly Fed policy.

Mike Larson: Yeah. Sometimes things do work out. I'll keep our fingers crossed, right?

Ed Clissold: Yeah. And when we're using the NDR is, like, I don't try to get too concerned about what might happen in the future. I have all my indicators and data that I'm -- that's where I spend most of my day on. It's boring and stuff, looking at indicators and stuff and trying to figure out where they are right now, but a lot of people want to know what we think might happen, and I think that's on our radar for concern for next year is, one way or the other, Fed policy might not be so market-friendly. And that comes right about the time the presidential cycle in the middle of the mid term year, things tend to be rocky, and so it all could come into play.

Mike Larson: You brought up the economy and markets and conditions at the end of the 1990s and early 2000s. So, I have to ask the question or at least bring it up. With AI, it's in the news every day. Is this a boom? Is it a bubble? Is it Dot-com 2? Is it not? What are your thoughts on that and what it means for an investor? I mean, if you're involved in that sector, you've been investing and made a lot of money. What do you tell clients when they come to you about the outlook there?

Ed Clissold: Yeah. So, a couple of things. One is, look, the market is concentrated in a way it really never has been before. If you look at the top 10 stocks in the S&P 500, depending on the day, they're roughly 40% of the S&P 500. For perspective, in 2000, they were 10%. I mean, I'm sorry. They were 30%, 10 percentage points lower. Even in the early '70s, the Nifty Fifty bubble era, they were 33%. So, yes, we are beholden to these Mag 7 AI-related companies whether we want to be or not. If you're invested in a cap-weighted index, that's where your money is allocated.

Now, in terms of where we are valuation-wise, so the second point is, if you were to say, look at a trailing price-to-earnings ratio, a forward price-to-earnings ratio, the S&P 500 is trading at near where it was in 2000. But, also, we were here in 2021. Now, we had a pretty nasty bear market in 2022. There wasn't a recession, but saw a 25% decline in the S&P. The point is, you could get a correction of this valuation predicament that we're in without a bubble popping. In fact, I'd argue that would be healthy.

If you contrast it to 2015, yeah, we had a growth scare, a shallow bear market. Because valuations were so much lower, that was less than 20% decline. Some people wouldn't even say it was a bear market. We classified one NDR because it lasted from May '15 to February '16. That was long enough. But regardless, the decline was much less peak to trough because you started a lower valuation. And so, even a growth scale without recession could lead to a bigger bear market.

I got to get to your real point, Mike, on the bubble. Right now, valuations are probably projecting a lot of gains from AI. We could get them, but eventually, we know that the last CapEx dollar spent in a cycle is usually not one well spent at all. And in some ways, this is a classic CapEx environment. And the reason why these Mag 7 companies have been so wonderful is that they're generating all this cash flow, and they return a lot for the shareholders.

And they still can return a lot to shareholders, but a lot more is being eaten up by the need to keep spending and growing faster and faster and faster, and they're all spending with each other. It feels like a circle of reference. And so, eventually, somebody's going to jump off the hamster wheel, and maybe everybody goes flying.

In terms of "Is this the end of the bubble or not?" As somebody who lived through 1999, it doesn't quite feel that way. And this is less about NDR indicators, more about the sentiment side of things. It really was a period where everybody piled in to just a few name. And this is something -- I've been on my soapbox about this for a few years when people say, oh, the top five stocks account for 60% of the gains of the S&P year to date. Well, that's how it works most years. It's a top-rated index. The biggest stocks that do well account for most of the gains.

It's okay for the generals to lead if the infantry are following. And right now, the infantry are following. Most stocks are trending up. What happened in the late '90s is it really got into a few names. So, in April '98, we hit a shallow bear market peak. We had long-term capital management, Russian ruble crisis. The Fed cut rates a few times, and Greenspan famously got all the bankers in the room and said, "Well, you made this mess with long-term capital. You fix it." And then the market roared out of those October '98 lows, and the Fed then pumped actual liquidity into the system.

Younger people, you may laugh at this. There was real concern everybody's going to take money out of ATMs because of Y2K, and so the Fed put money supply in the system, and money didn't go to the ATM. It went to the Nasdaq. Nasdaq almost doubled. But the average guy didn't -- the Advance Decline line, the running total of advancing stocks versus declining stock, peaked in April 1998. It never, never got above that level through all the 1999 into early 2000. The Value Line Geometric Index, which is an equal weighted composite, how the average stock is doing, likewise peaked in April 1998.

So, we haven't seen that. We got a new high in the A/D line just the other day. So, is it possible to bring the conversation about the Fed earlier? So, is it possible that we get the Fed pumping too much into the system, money goes where it's treated best, and that creates an AI bubble from here? Possibly. I just – my final note on the whole bubble discussion is, these things can go on for longer than what anybody thinks.

We all know trees don't go to the sky. The economy will not be 90% AI investment. So, eventually, this is going to come to an end. But right now, it doesn't feel like we're at the final throes of the bubble mania.

Mike Larson: Got it. Let me ask you this as we come to the tail end of our conversation. What other sectors -- you mentioned there is a lot more participation in this market. It's not all just tech. If you look at it from a sector breakdown, any other one or two opportunities that you think from your standpoint look particularly attractive here as we get closer to 2026?

Ed Clissold: So, on a sector basis, right now, we like tech, which obviously in the middle of that AI discussion. We also like utilities, which is somewhat AI-adjacent. It's also a way to maybe get some defensiveness in your portfolio. We have an eye on some of the more cyclical value areas, like materials. With all this focus on re-shoring and manufacturing, you would think that material stocks would participate in that.

And recently, they're very volatile, but if they can establish new uptrends, we would do that. The other one we have on our radar, not pulling the trigger on this yet, but it could be getting close, is healthcare. It's recently fallen to its weight in the S&P is below 10% for the first time since the late 1990s, and there's so much negative sentiment around healthcare. This is common after a new president is elected because they always campaign on ideas of shaking up healthcare systems.

Certainly, that's what's going on now, but on average, once you get six months or so after the new president takes office, a lot of that bad news is priced in. So, we want to see the momentum turn, but the cheap sector, under-loved, under-owned, could be a place to look going forward.

Mike Larson: Got it. Well, Ed, you're going to be joining us for the MoneyShow Masters Symposium in Sarasota here in December. Great to have you there. Glad you can make it. Just as a brief sneak peek, anything, themes, topics you think you're going to be touching on there for attendees?

Ed Clissold: So, I've got a lot of questions on. If small caps are going to be -- are finally ready to go, and so we'll probably talk a little bit about that and how growth stocks have continued to beat value stocks. And at NDR, we're really known for our investor sentiment work. We didn't touch on that a whole lot. I'd love to dive into the details about what's going on within sentiment, what part of the markets are showing frothiness and which ones are not.

Mike Larson: Perfect. Ed, thank you so much.

Ed Clissold: Appreciate the time, and looking forward to catching up in person.

Originally published on MoneyShow.com

data.title: Okta: Cheap Entry Into A High-Margin Growth Story
data.description:
Okta, Inc. (OKTA) is an American cybersecurity company that specializes in the identity and access management (IAM) landscape. The company's cloud-based software solution helps organizations protect against threats by securing user authentication, managing access to applications, and safeguarding digital assets.

Although the stock price has experienced a sell-off over the past 6 months, it has outperformed the benchmark over the past year. The company trades at a forward P/E of around 26, which may appear elevated, but I argue that it is cheap. The recent sell-off may offer a compelling opportunity for long-term investors to diversify in the high-margin, high-demand cybersecurity landscape, which should grow in the following years, given the arising threats due to artificial intelligence enhancements.

I think Okta is a Buy with a $108 price target over the next 12 months. It presents about 22% upside possibility and broader market outperformance. I think the company's stock price may mirror bottom-line expansion, which should be driven by high demand, double-digit top and bottom line growth, and premium margins.

FQ2 2026 Snapshot: The 20th Consecutive Double-Beat Quarter. Can The Streak Continue?

On August 26, the company delivered FQ2 2026 results. This was the 20th consecutive double-beat quarter, highlighting consistent performance and excellent execution by management. The market reacted with a roughly 2% appreciation in the stock price over the following trading day.

The cybersecurity company delivered $728 million in revenue, indicating a nearly 13% increase over the past 12 months, and $16 million above analysts' estimates. The bottom-line arrived at $0.91 in diluted EPS, about a 22% increase versus $0.72 in the same quarter last year, and $0.06 above analysts' forecasts. These results underscored a continuation in the top and bottom-line growth, which deserves a premium valuation.

Management highlighted that it achieved approximately 20,000 total customers. About 5,000 of them are spending more than $100,000, indicating high-quality services leading to a sticky customer base. I think this is extremely important and justifies a bullish narrative for the company.

The cybersecurity firm is also collaborating with other companies in the landscape to deliver innovative solutions and market-leading services for clients. For instance, on July 15, Okta announced an expanded partnership on new integrations with Palo Alto Networks to offer a unified security solution for their joint customers. This supports a bullish stance, highlighting a customer-focused business strategy, which may lead to higher consumer spending.

Management underlined the importance of its products. The security solutions appear to be a critical foundation for connection among users and technology. They cover cloud, security, and digital transformation. I think there is a significant necessity for cybersecurity products to take into account AI-related threats. To that, management highlighted Okta's end-to-end security solutions, offering visibility, governance, and remediation, and identifying non-human identities. I think that AI development presents a key tailwind for the company. Given its dominant stance in the identity and access management market, if Okta can sustain its leading position, it should be one of the key beneficiaries of the broader market growth.

In addition to the following tailwind, the identity and access management market was valued at roughly $13 billion in 2022, and is expected to triple in size over the following years to about $42 billion by 2030. This represents a 12.6% CAGR, and supports a bullish narrative for the stock. Okta is estimated to have about 41% market share in this landscape, which supports my thesis that if the company can sustain its dominant position, it is likely to benefit from broader market expansion leading to significant top and bottom-line growth.

In the presentation, management highlighted strong non-GAAP, which has been sustained at above an 80% level. The company underscored that subscription gross margin has reached 83.7% in the quarter, and that has slightly exceeded a total gross margin of 81.5%. I believe that this reflects strong fundamentals, which are sustained in parallel of a double-digit revenue growth. This deserves a higher premium and argues that the stock may actually be cheap at the current valuation.

The company is expected to announce FQ3 2026 results on November 26, after the market closes. Wall Street is anticipating approximately $730 million in revenue, implying roughly 10% growth on a year-over-year basis. The market is expecting $0.75 in diluted EPS, which would signal nearly 13% growth versus the same quarter last year. This would represent a continuation of double-digit expansion, marking significant performance and market dominance.

I believe that the company may be able to achieve these results. The company faces significant tailwinds tied to AI-related demand and threats related to the rapid development of the technology. Security in the connection between users and technology appears to be a necessity, and Okta is one of the key leaders in the segment.

Okta Appears To Be Undervalued, Tied To Double-Digit Growth, And Phenomenal Margins

The cybersecurity company currently trades at a forward P/E of 26.03, and although that presents a 2% premium to peers at 25.51, and roughly a 10% overvaluation compared to the average company in the S&P 500 at 23.62, I argue that the stock may be cheap.

The chart above highlights a significant correction the company faced from multiple perspectives since the beginning of 2024. Given this, I think that the sell-off may appear overdone, and the stock could rebound from these levels. This also reflects a multi-year low valuation, supporting that downside may be limited.

On a forward PEG (non-GAAP) basis of 1.53, the company appears undervalued, highlighting about a 15% discount to the sector median of 1.82. This supports my bullish thesis, indicating an undervalued level. On the other hand, the forward EV/Sales and Price/Sales ratios of 4.69 and 5.36, respectively, balance the bullish outlook and argue that Okta may actually be trading at a significant premium. These valuation metrics imply a 40% premium at the midpoint, which may weigh on the stock price.

Furthermore, these metrics may actually suggest that the market has partially priced in the company's future growth. If that is the case, although it continues growing at a double-digit pace, it may not necessarily result in the stock price appreciation.

On the upside, the company appears to be a low-leveraged business, and that is a significant argument for a bullish continuation. The company has $940 million in total obligations. Okta has $2.86 billion in cash and could pay its debt with ease. This appears appealing, as it leaves financial flexibility for management to use debt-related instruments, if that's needed.

The software company has been a phenomenal revenue growth story, so far. Over the past 12 months, it has grown its top-line by 12.68%, reflecting a 76% advantage versus peers at 7.19%. The forward revenue growth rate of 11.72% indicates that the trend of top-line expansion is likely to continue. This revenue growth appears to be roughly 30% higher than the average company in the S&P 500, at about 10%, which argues for a higher valuation.

The diluted EPS growth rate of 31% implies roughly a 2.7x premium versus the sector median of around 12%. This highlights that if the trend of business expansion continues, the company may appear even more compelling in the long term.

Okta operates at substantially above-market margins, fueling a bullish narrative. Gross profit margin (TTM) of roughly 77% implies a 55% premium versus peers at around 50%. The net income margin (TTM) of 6.08% represents nearly a 37% advantage versus the industry's average of 4.45%. This supports my stance, highlighting that Okta is a highly profitable company, operating at premium margins.

Overall, the company trades at industry-like valuations, although it grows top and bottom line at a more rapid pace. It remains a low-leveraged business, offering substantial margins. Okta is also tied to significant tailwinds related to the identity and access management market growth, and it has a dominant stance, which is likely to be sustained over the following years, because of innovative products and customer expansion.

Wall Street anticipates a $3.37 diluted EPS estimate for fiscal FY2026, highlighting a roughly 20% growth over the past 12 months. For fiscal FY2027, analysts expect $3.61 in diluted EPS, representing a 7% growth. I think the company can achieve such results, which would reflect a continuation in the demand, and are in line with the broader market expectations for the identity and access management market.

In addition, I believe that the market may rethink the thesis around Okta. Given AI-related threats, I think investor confidence may improve, and that could result in a higher premium for the software company. This is why I think that a 30x earnings multiple would be reasonable, justified by phenomenal margins and double-digit top and bottom line growth. If we apply a $3.61 fiscal FY2027 estimate to this earnings multiple, we arrive at my price target of $108, implying a 22% upside possibility. I think that the forward-looking markets may start pricing in sooner rather than later, and Okta may return to a more business-typical valuation level.

Main Risks And Concerns

There are risks and concerns tied to Okta that could meaningfully impact the stock price performance in the short term.

The identity and access management landscape appears to be highly competitive. Although Okta has a significant market share, pressure from Microsoft, and its Entra ID, CyberArk, and other companies could create fierce competition, and consumers may choose other alternatives. This could result in weaker-than-anticipated revenue growth or lower margins, which could weigh on the stock price.

The company is tied to security and data breach risks. As it is a cybersecurity name, any sort of breach could meaningfully impact its reputation, and that could be a significant challenge to outweigh. It also may lead to a financial impact, which could stress the stock.

Okta is also exposed to the macroeconomic headwinds. If IT-related spending slows down, the company could not experience a double-digit growth, and that could impact investor sentiment. This is an area to monitor for investors, whether IT-related companies face any slowdown in demand that could raise flags, and for Okta's business.

On the other hand, if none of the above materializes, Okta appears to be well-positioned to sustain its dominant position and benefit from broader market growth. I think it could appear a compelling opportunity for long-term investors who may be seeking a diversification into a high-margin landscape at a compelling valuation.

Conclusion: Okta Offers A Compelling Opportunity Into A High-Demand, High-Margin Market

I believe the software company offers an appealing opportunity to expand exposure to a high-demand, high-margin market. It remains a dominant player in the landscape, which argues for a bullish continuation. The cybersecurity market of identity and access management is expected to grow, following threats tied to AI expansion.

Okta appears to be trading at a fairly valued price, yet I argue that it actually is cheap. It grows both top and bottom lines at a double-digit pace, operates at substantially above-market margins, and remains a low-leverage business, which fuels a bullish outlook. It faces fierce competition that could impact market share and margins, but with innovative products and meaningful partnerships, it appears to be well-positioned to sustain its positive stance.

This is why I think Okta is a Buy with a $108 price target over the next 12 months. This suggests a 22% upside possibility, underscoring the likelihood of broader market outperformance. 42 Wall Street analysts forecast a roughly $121 price over the next year, implying 38% upside potential. This is possible, yet I favor a more conservative approach.

data.title: Joby Aviation: Patience Required
data.description:
Joby Aviation, Inc. (JOBY) is rallying on autonomous hype related to Nvidia (NVDA) partnership. The eVTOL company is far away from having autonomous aircraft, still working on certifying piloted aircraft. My investment thesis remains Neutral on the stock, especially on this rally to $17 on what amounts to no significant news.

Autonomous Future

Since Joby Aviation came public via the Reinvent Technology Partners SPAC back in 2021, the company has generally planned an autonomous flying taxi in the future. The air taxi company has pushed the service as a future opportunity towards the end of the decade with the potential to remove the cost of the pilot from a flight and add another paying passenger.

Joby Aviation just announced plans to work with Nvidia (NVDA) on the development of autonomous flight technology using their IGX Thor compute platform integrated into "Superpilot" technology for civil and military platforms. The collaboration promoted the concept of accelerating autonomous aviation without providing any concrete plans or goals.

The eVTOL partner is listed as the only aviation launch partner, but Nvidia already works with tons of companies working on autonomous vehicles. The AI compute giant is focused on platforms that can be widely adopted, not restrictive partnerships.

Besides, Joby Aviation bought Xwing last year to acquire the Superpilot software to advance autonomous flying plans. Xwing had already completed 250 fully autonomous flights and more than 500 auto-landings prior to the deal, which was over a year ago.

At the start of September, Joby Aviation remotely piloted a Cessna 208 aircraft. The company logged over 7,000 miles in the demonstration test, though the flights were remotely piloted.

For now, Joby Aviation shouldn't rally based on autonomous plans. The company must obtain FAA certification and successfully launch an air taxi service in New York by manufacturing certified aircraft before autonomous flying turns into a focus.

Focus On eVTOL Certification

The vastly more important story for Joby Aviation is the plans to fly piloted tests on Type Inspection Authorization (TIA) aircraft. At the time of the Q2 earnings call in August, the aircraft manufacturer was working on completing the assembly of the first of 5 aircraft to be used in FAA certification testing.

Joby Aviation will report Q3 earnings on November 5 and the whole focus will be on aircraft certification, not autonomous flights. About 3 months ago, the company had reached 70% certification of Stage 4 testing with some progress on Stage 5.

On the Q2'25 earnings call, the CEO outlined the flight testing plan as follows:

During this stage, Joby and FAA pilots will fly our aircraft to validate all of our certification work ahead of receiving a type certification. And I'm pleased to say, as we announced this morning, the first of 5 aircraft for TIA flight testing is headed to final assembly, and we remain on track to start flying our TIA aircraft with Joby pilots this year and to begin TIA certification flights with FAA pilots early next year.

Along with the announced deal with RAKTA in the UAE, Joby Aviation released that flight testing had topped 40,000 miles. The company should've logged far more test miles over the last month.

The company recently raised another $591 million by selling 35 million shares at $16.85 per share. Joby Aviation pushed the pro-forma Q3 ending cash balance of around $1.5 billion. The company ended Q2 with a cash hoard of $991 million, and the company likely burned $120+ million during the last quarter.

The stock has now seen the market cap reach $15 billion. Joby Aviation bought Blade Air Mobility's passenger business in the last quarter with a revenue run rate in the $105 million range.

Joby Aviation won't report any eVTOL revenues for a few more quarters, at least. The UAM business from Blade won't change the valuation equation much.

The company is still years away from being a $1+ billion business worthy of a $15 billion market cap. The stock continues to struggle moving above the $17 to $20 range due to stretched valuation.

Takeaway

The key investor takeaway is that Joby Aviation is leading the push into air taxi services around the globe. The company is on the verge of final testing with the FAA for aircraft certification, but the business has a long path to material revenues.

Investors should avoid buying the stock up here and possibly lock in some profits with the potential to re-acquire shares at lower prices.
